questions.text: Which of the following factors contributes least towards development of mucormycosis? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Broad spectrum antibiotics

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Among the listed factors, broad-spectrum antibiotics contribute the least towards the development of mucormycosis. The primary risk factors include diabetic ketoacidosis, long-term steroid treatment, neutropenia, lymphomas, leukemias, and other immunodeficiencies.

questions.text: Which of the following is the least common cause of bipedal edema? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Chronic Venous Insufficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic venous insufficiency typically causes unilateral or asymmetric leg swelling, making it the least common cause of symmetric bipedal edema.

questions.text: A patient was given 0.5% bupivacaine for supraclavicular brachial plexus block and suddenly developed hypotension and arrhythmias. Which of the following is the first line of management? ( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 20% IV Intralipid

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The patient experienced toxicity due to bupivacaine, a local anesthetic. The first-line treatment for local anesthetic toxicity, including bupivacaine toxicity, is the administration of 20% IV intralipid (lipid emulsion therapy). This treatment works by acting as a "lipid sink," which helps to absorb the lipophilic local anesthetic molecules and reduce their toxic effects on the cardiovascular and central nervous systems.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. IV Epinephrine : Suitable for cardiac arrest but not the first line for local anesthetic toxicity.
  • • Option A. IV Epinephrine
  • • Option C. IV Soda Bicarbonate : Used in cases of tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) toxicity causing ventricular arrhythmias but not for local anesthetic toxicity.
  • • Option C. IV Soda Bicarbonate
  • • Option D. IV Dobutamine : Used to treat heart failure and certain types of shock, but not specifically for local anesthetic toxicity
  • • Option D. IV Dobutamine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:
  • ➤ The first-line treatment for bupivacaine toxicity is the administration of 20% IV intralipid (lipid emulsion therapy).

questions.text: You work as a medical officer in a Primary Health Center (PHC). You are tasked with developing a strategy to address widespread anemia in the community. Considering the need for efficacy, safety, and ease of administration, which of the following options would you recommend for the prevention and treatment of anemia in this setting? (INICET NOV 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: FeSO4 + Vit C + Folate + Vit B12

questions.correct_answer: A. FeSO4 + Vit C + Folate + Vit B12
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) FeSO4 + Vit C + Folate + Vit B12

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The comprehensive and cost-effective approach, including FeSO4 + Vitamin C + Folate + Vitamin B12, is preferable for the widespread prevention and treatment of anemia in a community setting, especially in a resource-limited Primary Health Center (PHC).
  • ➤ The comprehensive and cost-effective approach, including FeSO4 + Vitamin C + Folate + Vitamin B12, is preferable for the widespread prevention and treatment of anemia in a community setting, especially in a resource-limited Primary Health Center (PHC).

questions.text: MC direct cause of Maternal mortality is? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Post partum haemorrhage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Post-partum hemorrhage is the most common direct cause and anemia is the MC indirect cause of the maternal mortality in India, and PPH is also the overall leading cause of maternal deaths in the country.
  • ➤ India MMR (SRS 2023) – 97 per 1 lakh live births

questions.text: Which of the following diuretic acts on the site X shown in the figure? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Hydrochlorothiazide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic that acts on the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) by inhibiting the Na-Cl symporter, thereby reducing sodium reabsorption and promoting diuresis. This makes it effective for treating conditions such as hypertension and edema. Other diuretics like furosemide, spironolactone, and acetazolamide act on different parts of the nephron and have distinct mechanisms of action.

questions.text: What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Becker's naevus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Becker's naevus is a patchy, hyperpigmented lesion that often develops during adolescence and may include hypertrichosi s, distinguishing it from congenital conditions such as Mongolian spots, Naevus of Ito, and congenital melanocytic naevi.
  • ➤ Becker's naevus
  • ➤ patchy, hyperpigmented
  • ➤ adolescence
  • ➤ hypertrichosi
  • ➤ congenital

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Bolognia 4 th edition, chapter 112, page no 2232
  • ↳ Question Level – EASY
  • ↳ Question Level – EASY
  • ↳ Question Id-7443 Unique Key-Q6167342
  • ↳ Question Id-7443 Unique Key-Q6167342

questions.text: A patient complains of ptosis and increasing muscle weakness by evening. This is relieved by neostigmine. What is the likely diagnosis? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Myasthenia gravis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Myasthenia gravis is characterized by ptosis and muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest. The diagnosis is supported by the relief of symptoms with acetylcholinesterase inhibitors like neostigmine. This condition results from autoantibodies against acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction.

questions.text: Anterior ethmoidal sinus drains into: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Middle meatus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The anterior ethmoidal sinus, along with the maxillary and frontal sinuses, drains into the middle meatus of the nasal cavity.

questions.text: A 75-year-old patient suffers with extracapsular femoral neck fracture. What would be the most appropriate management option for her management? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Intramedullary nailing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intramedullary nailing , while useful for certain types of fractures, is generally the first choice for extracapsular femoral neck fractures in elderly patients due to the risks and potential complications associated with the procedure. Cephalomedullary nailing is done in such cases.
  • ➤ Intramedullary nailing , while useful for certain types of fractures, is generally the first choice for extracapsular femoral neck fractures in elderly patients due to the risks and potential complications associated with the procedure.
  • ➤ Cephalomedullary nailing is done in such cases.

questions.text: In a gunshot case, blackening is noted surrounding a firearm entry wound. Blackening occurs mainly due to: (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  D. Black smoke particles

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The presence of blackening, soot, and unburnt gunpowder at a gunshot entry wound provides crucial information about the distance and angle of the shot.

questions.text: Which of these options is NOT a means of directly transmitting communicable diseases? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Droplet nuclei

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Droplet nuclei represent an indirect transmission method, as they can remain airborne for long periods and travel over distances, whereas vertical transmission , contact with soil , and droplet transmission are forms of direct transmission of communicable diseases.
  • ➤ Droplet nuclei
  • ➤ indirect transmission
  • ➤ vertical transmission
  • ➤ contact with soil
  • ➤ droplet transmission
  • ➤ direct transmission

questions.text: What is Prosopagnosia?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.correct_answer: C. Difficulty in identifying known faces
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Difficulty in identifying known faces

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Prosopagnosia (also known as face blindness or facial agnosia) is a neurological disorder characterized by the inability to recognize faces. An autonomic response may be produced in response to a familiar face.
  • • Note - Prosopagnosia is not related to memory dysfunction, memory loss, impaired vision, or learning disabilities. The disorder is thought to be the result of congenital influence, damage, or impairment in a fold in the brain that appears to coordinate the neural systems controlling facial perception and memory (right fusiform gyrus).
  • • Note
  • • Face recognitions is represented mainly in the right inferior temporal lobe, but left lobe is also involved and injury to this area cause prosopagnosia. Prosopagnosia can result from stroke, traumatic brain injury (TBI), or certain neurodegenerative diseases.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Impairment of consciousness : Incorrect because prosopagnosia specifically relates to difficulty in recognizing faces, not general impairments of consciousness.
  • • Option A. Impairment of consciousness
  • • Option B. Being unaware of one's problems : Incorrect as this describes anosognosia, not prosopagnosia.
  • • Option B. Being unaware of one's problems
  • • Option D. Failure to identify objects : Incorrect because this defines object agnosia, whereas prosopagnosia is specifically the inability to recognize faces.
  • • Option D. Failure to identify objects

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prosopagnosia is the inability to recognize faces, often due to damage to the right fusiform gyrus and related brain areas involved in facial perception and memory, distinct from general memory loss or vision impairment.
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ Autotopagnosia - inability to recognize or to orient different parts of one's own body Simultagnosia -the inability to perceive more than one object at a time. Somatagnosia - inability to identify any part of the body, either one's own or another's body Tactile agnosia (stereognosia) - inability to recognize objects by touch
  • ➤ Autotopagnosia - inability to recognize or to orient different parts of one's own body
  • ➤ Autotopagnosia
  • ➤ Simultagnosia -the inability to perceive more than one object at a time.
  • ➤ Simultagnosia
  • ➤ Somatagnosia - inability to identify any part of the body, either one's own or another's body
  • ➤ Somatagnosia
  • ➤ Tactile agnosia (stereognosia) - inability to recognize objects by touch
  • ➤ Tactile agnosia (stereognosia)

questions.text: An elderly woman presented with symptoms of confusion, thirst, and abdominal pain. On examination, she had pallor and thoracic spine tenderness. X-ray spine showed osteolytic lesions. Her lab investigations showed the following findings: Hb - 6.9g/dL, WBC 4000/cm3 with normal differential count, Serum calcium 13mg/dL, Creatinine 2.3mg/dL, Total protein 9g/dL, Albumin 2.4g/dL. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Multiple myeloma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Multiple myeloma is characterized by anemia, hypercalcemia, renal failure, and bone lesions.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a method of administering free-flow oxygen in a neonate? (INICET MAY 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Bag and mask ventilation with oxygen inlet

options.label: D
options.text: Bag and mask ventilation without oxygen inlet

questions.correct_answer: D. Bag and mask ventilation without oxygen inlet
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Free-flow oxygen can be administered using methods that allow passive flow of oxygen, such as a face mask or tubing near the mouth and nose. Bag and mask ventilation without an oxygen inlet does not allow for free-flow oxygen administration.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female comes to the OPD with complaints of “feeling tensed” and having “stomach upset” symptoms, including heartburn and diarrhea. She states that she has been having these symptoms since she was 25 years old and that her family members are also usually tense and “nervous.” Which of the following symptoms are also likely to be present in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tingling of extremities

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients with Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD) may experience somatic symptoms like tingling of extremities due to heightened anxiety and nervous system activity.

References:

  • ↳ Option B. Ideas of Reference:
  • ↳ Option C. Hallucinations: Hallucinations involve sensory perceptions without external stimuli and are common in psychotic disorders, such as schizophrenia, but not in anxiety disorders.
  • ↳ Option C. Hallucinations:
  • ↳ Option D. Neologisms: Neologisms are newly coined words or phrases that have meaning only to the person using them and are commonly seen in formal thought disorders like schizophrenia. This is not a symptom seen in GAD.
  • ↳ Option D. Neologisms:

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with heart failure and poorly controlled type 2 diabetes (HbA1c of 7.8%) presents with progressive dyspnea. Which is the preferred antidiabetic drug? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dapagliflozin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For patients with type 2 diabetes and heart failure, SGLT2 inhibitors like dapagliflozin are the preferred antidiabetic medications due to their proven benefits in reducing heart failure progression, hospitalizations, and mortality.

questions.text: Which of the following is a tributary of the inferior vena cava? ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Left inferior phrenic vein

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The tributaries of the inferior vena cava include veins that drain directly into it without first passing through another vein, except for the hepatic veins.

questions.text: A patient with renal insufficiency had very low urine output, pedal edema, headache, and a blood pressure of 160/90. Which antihypertensive medication can be used? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Amlodipine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Amlodipine is the preferred antihypertensive medication for patients with renal insufficiency, as it effectively lowers blood pressure without negatively impacting renal function.

questions.text: A servant was sexually assaulted by her boss. There was presence of white stains on the clothes of the victim. Barberio's test was performed on the stains. Which of the following is detected by this test?

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with 15 days of fever and altered sensorium for 1 day. A rapid diagnostic test was done, and Plasmodium falciparum was diagnosed. Which of the following is not a complication? ( INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Arterial pH >7.2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diagnostic criteria for identifying complicated falciparum malaria, based on clinical and laboratory findings:
  • ➤ Arterial pH : An arterial pH of less than 7.25 is indicative of complicated falciparum malaria. Bicarbonate Levels : A bicarbonate level of less than 15 is also a sign of complicated falciparum malaria. Base Deficit : A base deficit of more than 8 is another indicator of severe disease. Hemoglobin : A hemoglobin level of less than 5, or the presence of hemoglobinuria, are significant markers of severity. Venous Lactate : A venous lactate level of more than 5 further confirms the complexity and severity of the malaria infection. Blood Glucose : A blood glucose level less than 40 mg/dL is a critical indicator of complicated falciparum malaria. Creatinine Levels : A creatinine level exceeding 3 mg/dL points to significant renal impairment associated with severe malaria. Urine Output : A urine output of less than 400 mL per day, despite adequate rehydration with IV fluids, also signifies complicated falciparum malaria.
  • ➤ Arterial pH : An arterial pH of less than 7.25 is indicative of complicated falciparum malaria.
  • ➤ Arterial pH
  • ➤ Bicarbonate Levels : A bicarbonate level of less than 15 is also a sign of complicated falciparum malaria.
  • ➤ Bicarbonate Levels
  • ➤ Base Deficit : A base deficit of more than 8 is another indicator of severe disease.
  • ➤ Base Deficit
  • ➤ Hemoglobin : A hemoglobin level of less than 5, or the presence of hemoglobinuria, are significant markers of severity.
  • ➤ Hemoglobin
  • ➤ Venous Lactate : A venous lactate level of more than 5 further confirms the complexity and severity of the malaria infection.
  • ➤ Venous Lactate
  • ➤ Blood Glucose : A blood glucose level less than 40 mg/dL is a critical indicator of complicated falciparum malaria.
  • ➤ Blood Glucose
  • ➤ Creatinine Levels : A creatinine level exceeding 3 mg/dL points to significant renal impairment associated with severe malaria.
  • ➤ Creatinine Levels
  • ➤ Urine Output : A urine output of less than 400 mL per day, despite adequate rehydration with IV fluids, also signifies complicated falciparum malaria.
  • ➤ Urine Output

questions.text: A male patient presents with sensory loss and weakness of limbs for 3 months. He also has angular stomatitis. On examination, there is loss of proprioception, vibration sensations, UMN type of lower limb weakness, and absent ankle reflex. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: D
options.text: Subacute combined degeneration of the cord

questions.correct_answer: D. Subacute combined degeneration of the cord
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Subacute combined degeneration of the cord

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Subacute combined degeneration of the cord due to vitamin B12 deficiency presents with sensory loss, UMN signs in the lower limbs, and absent ankle reflex, along with other signs of vitamin deficiency like angular stomatitis.

questions.text: Thiamine deficiency causes lactic acidosis due to inhibition of: ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) PDH (Pyruvate dehydrogenase)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pyruvate dehydrogenase is the enzyme affected in a patient with thiamine deficiency who develops lactic acidosis.
  • ➤ Enzyme performing oxidative decarboxylation need vitamin B1 for their reaction. Some examples are:
  • ➤ PDH Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase Isocitrate dehydrogenase Branched chain keto acid dehydrogenase
  • ➤ PDH
  • ➤ Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
  • ➤ Isocitrate dehydrogenase
  • ➤ Branched chain keto acid dehydrogenase
  • ➤ Additional Information:
  • ➤ Additional Information:
  • ➤ Marker for B1 deficiency is Transketolase activity Coenzyme for simple decarboxylation: B6 Marker for B2 deficiency is RBC glutathione reductase activity
  • ➤ Marker for B1 deficiency is Transketolase activity
  • ➤ Transketolase activity
  • ➤ Coenzyme for simple decarboxylation: B6
  • ➤ Marker for B2 deficiency is RBC glutathione reductase activity
  • ➤ RBC glutathione reductase activity

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient is brought to the emergency department following a suspected stroke. Upon assessment, it is noted that the patient is able to speak fluently, but the words uttered lack coherent meaning and lacks understanding. Which type of aphasia is most likely present in this patient? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Wernicke's aphasia is characterized by fluent speech that lacks coherent meaning. Patients with this condition can speak in long sentences with normal grammar, but their speech may include unnecessary or made-up words, making it difficult for others to understand.
  • • This condition results from a lesion in Wernicke's area, which is responsible for language comprehension. In this scenario, the patient's ability to speak fluently yet produce nonsensical speech indicates a disruption in language comprehension, hallmark features of Wernicke's aphasia.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Conduction aphasia: This type of aphasia is caused by a lesion in the arcuate fasciculus , which connects Wernicke's and Broca's areas. Patients with conduction aphasia have good comprehension and fluent speech but struggle with repetition and may make phonemic errors.
  • • Option B. Conduction aphasia:
  • • arcuate fasciculus
  • • Option C. Anomic aphasia: Anomic aphasia is characterized by difficulty in finding the correct words, particularly nouns and verbs. Patients can understand speech and have fluent and grammatically correct speech but have trouble naming objects.
  • • Option C. Anomic aphasia:
  • • Option D. Broca's aphasia: This type of aphasia results from a lesion in Broca's area, leading to non-fluent , halting speech with good comprehension. Patients with Broca's aphasia have difficulty forming complete sentences and may produce short, broken phrases.
  • • Option D. Broca's aphasia:
  • • non-fluent

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wernicke's aphasia is identified by fluent but nonsensical speech due to impaired language comprehension.
  • ➤ fluent but nonsensical speech

questions.text: A toddler was found playing alone and was brought to the emergency department with complaints of difficulty in swallowing for the past few hours. An X-ray was performed, and the image revealed as shown in AP view. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)

options.label: D
options.text: Soft tissue calcification in the neck

questions.correct_answer: B. Foreign body in the esophagus
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Foreign body in the esophagus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of pediatric ingestion of foreign bodies, the esophagus is a common site where objects can become lodged. Radiographic evaluation typically shows a foreign body in the esophagus with a flat surface seen on the AP view and the edge on the lateral view. Immediate recognition and appropriate intervention are crucial to prevent complications.
  • ➤ In cases of pediatric ingestion of foreign bodies, the esophagus is a common site where objects can become lodged.
  • ➤ Radiographic evaluation typically shows a foreign body in the esophagus with a flat surface seen on the AP view and the edge on the lateral view.
  • ➤ Immediate recognition and appropriate intervention are crucial to prevent complications.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with a bone marrow aspirate having the finding as shown in the image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Glucocerebrosidase defect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gaucher's disease is the most common lysosomal storage disorder, caused by a glucocerebrosidase deficiency, leading to the accumulation of Gaucher cells with a characteristic crumpled tissue paper-like appearance in bone marrow aspirates.

questions.text: A 51-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with complaints of hematuria. Upon examination, he is found to be normotensive and has pedal edema. Further investigations reveal a lack of glycosuria and a creatinine level of 9. A renal biopsy is performed, and the results are shown below. Which of the following investigations should be conducted to identify the underlying disease? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Anti GBM antibodies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Testing for anti-GBM antibodies is crucial in the diagnosis of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) with crescents on histology, particularly for identifying Type I RPGN (anti-GBM disease).

questions.text: A boy born to a normal father and mother had Hemophilia. Detailed history taking revealed that the mother's side had a family history of similar affected individuals. The children born to this boy are likely to have which of the following? (NEET PG 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: All boys and girl children equally affected

options.label: B
options.text: 50% boys affected and no girl children unaffected

options.label: C
options.text: No boy affected and 50% girl children are carrier

options.label: D
options.text: 25% boy affected and 25% girl children are carrier

questions.correct_answer: C. No boy affected and 50% girl children are carrier
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) No boy affected and 50% girl children are carrier

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In X-linked recessive disorders like hemophilia, affected males do not transmit the condition to their sons, but their daughters have a 50% chance of being carriers.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient presents with lower abdominal pain, frequent urination, and signs of dehydration. Physical examination reveals abdominal tenderness, and urine analysis indicates sterile pyuria. An image is provided. What is the most likely condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Putty kidney

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Putty kidney is a radiographic finding associated with genitourinary tuberculosis, characterized by homogenous, ground glass-like calcifications in the kidney. This condition typically presents with symptoms such as sterile pyuria, and diagnosis is confirmed through specific TB testing and imaging modalities like CT urography. Treatment usually involves antitubercular drugs and may require surgical intervention.
  • ➤ Putty kidney is a radiographic finding associated with genitourinary tuberculosis, characterized by homogenous, ground glass-like calcifications in the kidney.
  • ➤ This condition typically presents with symptoms such as sterile pyuria, and diagnosis is confirmed through specific TB testing and imaging modalities like CT urography.
  • ➤ Treatment usually involves antitubercular drugs and may require surgical intervention.

questions.text: A middle aged male presented with features of neck swelling, exophthalmos, sweating, tachycardia and tremors. Which of the following is the likely associated finding in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Anti thyroid receptor antibody

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Graves' disease is associated with anti-thyroid receptor antibodies (TSI), which stimulate the thyroid gland to produce excess thyroid hormones, leading to hyperthyroidism. The presence of neck swelling, exophthalmos, and other hyperthyroid symptoms strongly suggests this diagnosis.
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins 10 th / 1081
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins 10 th / 1081

questions.text: A 25-year primigravida is on indomethacin (25mg TDS) for polyhydramnios till 35 weeks. What abnormality can the fetus have if she goes into labor now? (NEET PG 2021)

options.label: C
options.text: Premature closure of the ductus arteriosus

options.label: D
options.text: Premature closure of the ductus venosus

questions.correct_answer: C. Premature closure of the ductus arteriosus
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Premature closure of the ductus arteriosus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Indomethacin and Fetal Effects:
  • • Indomethacin and Fetal Effects:
  • • Indomethacin is a non-selective cyclo-oxygenase inhibitor used in obstetrics primarily for two indications: Polyhydramnios: To reduce the excessive amniotic fluid. Tocolytic in preterm labor: To delay preterm labor. Mechanism: Indomethacin works by inhibiting the production of prostaglandins, which are important for maintaining the patency of the ductus arteriosus in the fetus. Risks: When used beyond 32 weeks of gestation, indomethacin can cause premature closure of the ductus arteriosus , leading to complications such as: Pulmonary hypertension Right ventricular hypertrophy Heart failure
  • • Indomethacin is a non-selective cyclo-oxygenase inhibitor used in obstetrics primarily for two indications: Polyhydramnios: To reduce the excessive amniotic fluid. Tocolytic in preterm labor: To delay preterm labor.
  • • Indomethacin
  • • Polyhydramnios: To reduce the excessive amniotic fluid. Tocolytic in preterm labor: To delay preterm labor.
  • • Polyhydramnios: To reduce the excessive amniotic fluid.
  • • Polyhydramnios:
  • • Tocolytic in preterm labor: To delay preterm labor.
  • • Tocolytic in preterm labor:
  • • Mechanism: Indomethacin works by inhibiting the production of prostaglandins, which are important for maintaining the patency of the ductus arteriosus in the fetus.
  • • Mechanism:
  • • Risks: When used beyond 32 weeks of gestation, indomethacin can cause premature closure of the ductus arteriosus , leading to complications such as: Pulmonary hypertension Right ventricular hypertrophy Heart failure
  • • Risks:
  • • premature closure of the ductus arteriosus
  • • Pulmonary hypertension Right ventricular hypertrophy Heart failure
  • • Pulmonary hypertension
  • • Right ventricular hypertrophy
  • • Heart failure
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Flap closure of foramen ovale: The foramen ovale normally closes soon after birth when the pressure in the left atrium exceeds the pressure in the right atrium. Indomethacin does not affect the closure of the foramen ovale.
  • • Option A. Flap closure of foramen ovale:
  • • Option B. Patent ductus arteriosus: Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is a condition where the ductus arteriosus remains open after birth. Indomethacin is actually used to treat PDA by promoting its closure, not causing it.
  • • Option B. Patent ductus arteriosus:
  • • Option D. Premature closure of the ductus venosus: The ductus venosus allows oxygenated blood from the umbilical vein to bypass the liver and flow directly into the inferior vena cava. Indomethacin does not influence the closure of the ductus venosus.
  • • Option D. Premature closure of the ductus venosus:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Indomethacin can cause premature closure of the ductus arteriosus if used beyond 32 weeks of gestation.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 679, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 679, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: A patient presented with fever for 5 days and you are suspecting enteric fever. What is the best way to diagnose? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Blood Cultures

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Enteric fever, commonly known as typhoid fever, is typically caused by the bacteria Salmonella typhi or Salmonella paratyphi. The best diagnostic method depends on the stage of the disease.
  • • For a patient presenting with fever for 5 days (in the first week of illness), blood cultures are the most reliable diagnostic method. During the first week, the bacteria are most likely to be present in the bloodstream, making blood cultures highly effective for identifying the pathogen.
  • • blood cultures
  • • Key points:
  • • Key points:
  • • Blood cultures: The best diagnostic method for enteric fever during the first week of illness, as the bacteria are present in the blood. Bone marrow cultures: While they have the highest sensitivity at any stage of the disease, they are more invasive and less commonly performed compared to blood cultures.
  • • Blood cultures: The best diagnostic method for enteric fever during the first week of illness, as the bacteria are present in the blood.
  • • Blood cultures:
  • • Bone marrow cultures: While they have the highest sensitivity at any stage of the disease, they are more invasive and less commonly performed compared to blood cultures.
  • • Bone marrow cultures:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Urine cultures: These are not typically useful in the early stages of enteric fever and are more relevant in the later stages of the disease.
  • • Option B. Urine cultures:
  • • Option C. Widal test: This serological test detects antibodies against Salmonella antigens, but it is less specific and sensitive, especially in the early stages. It also has a higher rate of false positives and is not recommended as the primary diagnostic tool in the first week.
  • • Option C. Widal test:
  • • Option D. Stool cultures: These can be useful later in the disease when the bacteria are shed in the stool, but they are not the best diagnostic method during the first week.
  • • Option D. Stool cultures:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For diagnosing enteric fever in the first week of illness, blood cultures are the most effective and reliable method.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents in the ENT OPD with complaints of pain and discharge from the ear. Examination reveals the following findings. What is the best line of treatment? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Clotrimazole ear drops

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient presents with pain and discharge from the ear, and the examination shows black-headed filamentous growths on the otoendoscopic picture. This indicates a fungal infection, specifically otomycosis caused by Aspergillus niger. The best treatment for otomycosis is an antifungal agent.
  • • otomycosis caused by Aspergillus niger.
  • • Clotrimazole an antifungal and is typically used to treat otomycosis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Clotrimoxazole ear drops : Not an antifungal drug.
  • • Option A. Clotrimoxazole ear drops
  • • Option B. Ciprofloxacin ear drops: Ciprofloxacin is an antibiotic and is used to treat bacterial infections. It does not have antifungal properties.
  • • Option B. Ciprofloxacin ear drops:
  • • Option D. Wax softening ear drops: Wax softening ear drops contain ingredients like paradichlorobenzene, chlorbutol, and turpentine oil, which are used to soften ear wax. This treatment is irrelevant in the context of a fungal infection.
  • • Option D. Wax softening ear drops:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Otomycosis, a fungal infection of the ear, caused by Aspergillus niger, should be treated with antifungal agents like Clotrimazole ear drops.

questions.text: Which of the following manifestations is typically associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 syndrome? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Parathyroid hyperplasia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Parathyroid hyperplasia is a hallmark of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 syndrome, often leading to primary hyperparathyroidism, and distinguish it from other conditions associated with MEN2.

questions.text: A patient is found on a railway track with hot dry skin, raised temperature, dilated pupils, slurred speech, and a staggering gait. Which of the following is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dhatura poisoning

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dhatura poisoning is characterized by anticholinergic symptoms such as hot dry skin, hyperthermia, dilated pupils, slurred speech, and a staggering gait, distinguishing it from other causes of altered mental status.
  • ➤ Dhatura poisoning

questions.text: A newborn is brought with evisceration of bowel loops from a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus. The most probable diagnosis is: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Gastroschisis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gastroschisis is a congenital defect characterized by the herniation of abdominal contents through a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus, without a protective sac covering the contents.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with bitemporal hemianopia. CT is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Craniopharyngioma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A calcified lesion in the suprasellar region suggests craniopharyngioma . It is derived from Rathke's pouch.
  • • calcified lesion in the suprasellar region
  • • suggests craniopharyngioma
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: Pituitary adenomas are seen in the sellar region in adults. Macroadenomas are seen as snowman or figure of eight appearance.
  • • Option A:
  • • Macroadenomas are seen as snowman or figure of eight appearance.
  • • Option B: Meningioma is a supratentorial tumor, mainly in the parasagittal region. A classical Dural tail is seen.
  • • Option B:
  • • Dural tail
  • • Option D : Oligodendroglioma is exclusively found in the cerebral hemispheres, most commonly in the frontal lobes. Up to 90% of oligodendrogliomas contain visible calcification on CT .
  • • Option D
  • • calcification on CT

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Craniopharyngioma should be considered in pediatric patients presenting with visual disturbances and evidence of a calcified mass in the suprasellar region on imaging. This diagnosis is important due to the potential impact on the optic pathways and pituitary gland function, requiring careful management.

References:

  • ↳ Reference– Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 742

questions.text: A patient arrives at the emergency department following severe maxillofacial trauma sustained in a road traffic accident. The airway is compromised, and immediate intervention is required. What is the most appropriate immediate management? (FMGE JAN 2024)

options.label: D
options.text: Bag mask ventilation with jaw thrust

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cricothyroidotomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of severe maxillofacial trauma with compromised airway, cricothyroidotomy is the most appropriate immediate management to establish an emergency airway when orotracheal intubation is not feasible or contraindicated.

questions.text: All of the following are features of Crohn's disease except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Lead pipe appearance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/IBD

questions.text: Identify the muscle forming the marked boundary: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Extensor pollicis longus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image shows the anatomical snuff box, a triangular depression at the base of the thumb. The anatomical snuff box has specific boundaries, and the arrow is pointing to the posterior (posteromedial) boundary. The muscle forming the posterior boundary of the anatomical snuff box is the extensor pollicis longus.
  • • The mnemonic "aage longus peechhe longus beech mein brevis" helps remember the boundaries:
  • • The mnemonic "aage longus peechhe longus beech mein brevis" helps remember the boundaries:
  • • Anterior (anterolateral) boundary: Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis Posterior (posteromedial) boundary: Extensor pollicis longus Between the two boundaries: Extensor pollicis brevis
  • • Anterior (anterolateral) boundary: Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis
  • • Anterior (anterolateral) boundary:
  • • Posterior (posteromedial) boundary: Extensor pollicis longus
  • • Posterior (posteromedial) boundary:
  • • Between the two boundaries: Extensor pollicis brevis
  • • Between the two boundaries:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Extensor pollicis brevis: This muscle forms part of the anterior boundary and the floor of the anatomical snuff box, not the posterior boundary.
  • • Option A. Extensor pollicis brevis:
  • • Option B. Abductor pollicis longus: This muscle forms part of the anterior boundary of the anatomical snuff box, not the posterior boundary.
  • • Option B. Abductor pollicis longus:
  • • Option C. Abductor pollicis brevis : This muscle is not related to the boundaries of the anatomical snuff box. It is a muscle of the thenar eminence, responsible for abduction of the thumb.
  • • Option C. Abductor pollicis brevis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The extensor pollicis longus forms the posterior boundary of the anatomical snuff box.
